Co2+ immobilized on highly ordered mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (ompg-C3N4/Co2+) as an efficient and recyclable heterogeneous catalyst for one-pot tandem selective photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation Hossein Ghafuri ⁎ Ghazaleh Jafari Afsaneh Rashidizadeh Faranak Manteghi Catalysts and Organic Synthesis Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran, 16846-13114, Iran Catalysts and Organic Synthesis Research Laboratory Department of Chemistry Iran University of Science and Technology Tehran 16846-13114 Iran Catalysts and Organic Synthesis Research Laboratory, Department of Chemistry, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran16846-13114, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Design and synthesis of efficient heterogeneous photocatalysts is an important task for practical applications due to the increasing environmental challenges and energy crisis. In this work, Co2+ modified highly ordered mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (ompg-C3N4/Co2+) was prepared through a simple procedure involving sonication treatment. The obtained catalyst was characterized using FT-IR, XRD, ICP-OES, FE-SEM, UV–vis DRS, N2 adsorption-desorption, and TGA. It was found that the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ can function as a multifunctional heterogeneous photocatalyst for the one-pot tandem selective photo-oxidation/ Knoevenagel condensation. More interestingly, the obtained ompg-C3N4/Co2+ represented a high photocatalytic activity in benzyl alcohol oxidation without any oxidant under air atmosphere and visible light irradiation. Keywords Heterogeneous photocatalysis Co2+ modified highly ordered mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (ompg-C3N4/Co2+) Oxidative tandem reaction Knoevenagel condensation 1 Introduction Over the past decade, designing unique heterogeneous photocatalysis for transformation of solar power to viable forms of energy have attracted worldwide attention due to global warming and energy crisis. Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) is a green and potential material for photocatalysis with two-dimensional layer structure that can be easily synthesized through thermal polycondensation of the low cost and abundant precursors containing dicyandiamide, urea, melamine, cyanamide, and thiourea. g-C3N4 as an organic and metal-free polymeric semiconductor possesses promising features such as large surface area, high physicochemical and thermal stability, and electronic band structure owing to the sp2 hybridization of nitrogen and carbon atoms to form tri-s-triazine units which are linked by planar amino units generating a stacked two-dimensional π-conjugated graphitic- like layers. Moreover, graphitic carbon nitride with a moderate band gap energy is a valuable semiconductor can adsorb a large fraction of energy in the visible region to produce chemical energy [1,2]. In view of its properties, g-C3N4 has been employed in diverse fields including energy storage, fuel cells, degradation of contaminant, redox reactions, CO2 reduction, water splitting, and heterogeneous catalyst or catalyst supports [3–9]. Nevertheless, due to the low specific surface area, deficient electron-hole pair separation, quick recombination probability of photoinduced carriers, and poor absorption in visible light region, the photocatalytic performance of the pure g-C3N4 was limited. Hence, many attempts have been made to overcome these obstacles and improve the photoactivity of the pristine g-C3N4, which include doping with heteroatoms (such as sulfur, oxygen, boron, phosphorus, and halogen), metal deposition, hybridizing with noble metals, heterogeneous semiconductors, metal oxides, and designing porous textural [10–16]. Selective oxidation reactions are the most essential chemical transformations in organic synthesis. Particularly, the carbonyl compounds obtained from the selective oxidation of hydroxyl groups, are extensively applied as the indispensable intermediates in the synthesis of fine chemicals, agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, food and fragrances, and vitamins [17,18]. Generally, traditional oxidation reactions involved the use of stoichiometric amount of hazardous or corrosive oxidizing agents (such as MnO2, KMnO4, ClO−, Cr(VI), CrO3, Cl2) under high pressure and temperature conditions, which lead to harmful byproducts and generate tremendous heavy metal wastes [19]. Accordingly, a promising alternative green process for selective oxidation of alcohols under mild conditions is still in demand. Up to date, semiconductor photocatalysts are considered to be the most effective route for using renewable solar energy. Sustainable heterogeneous photocatalysts have attracted extensive application in oxidation reactions due to their selectivity, excellent stability, and use of H2O2, O2 or air as oxidant, which are clearly more environmentally benign than inorganic oxidants [20–23]. Recently, Wang and coworkers employed mpg-C3N4 as a metal-free photocatalyst to active O2 for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohols under visible light irradiation. They have demonstrated a potential pathway for the selective oxidation reaction of benzyl alcohols to benzaldehydes with avoiding the cost and toxic oxidants [24]. Chen have described acid- modification had a significant influence on the photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4 for the selective aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohols with dioxygen as the oxidant. We are thus inspired to modify g-C3N4 for selective oxidation of benzyl alcohols to their corresponding aldehydes under visible light source and mild reaction conditions [25]. Consequently, the photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4 remains an attractive subject in the field of material science. We are thus inspired to modify the g-C3N4 for the one-pot tandem aerobic photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation of alcohols with malononitrile. Carbon-carbon bond forming via Knoevenagel condensation between carbonyl compounds and active methylenes is the most important strategies in organic synthesis. The obtained α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds through the Knoevenagel condensation have wide applications in natural and biological products synthesis [26]. Various base and acid catalysts have been applied for the Knoevenagel condensation including amine functionalized MOFs, carbon nanotubes, C60, ionic liquids, GO, and also ZnCl2, Ni-SiO2, and Vanadium-substituted phosphomolybdic acid [27–35]. One-pot tandem reactions have received a great deal of attention by reducing energy consumption and production of wastes, optimizing the use of substrates and solvents, and increasing economic efficiency. Therefore, developing an environmentally benign strategy for the one-pot tandem synthesis of benzylidene malononitrile via oxidation-Knoevenagel condensation reaction is a major challenge for scientists. In recent years, several bifunctional catalysts were reported for the preparation of benzylidene malononitrile derivatives through one-pot consecutive oxidation-Knoevenagel condensation reaction such as Cu3TATAT-3, NH2-MIL-101(Fe), Ru/UiO-66, and MNP@PIL/W [36–39]. Following our researchers into the preparation of heterogeneous catalysts [40–46] and with the goal of designing a novel photocatalytic system for the tandem oxidative condensation reactions that require a green oxidant and mild condition to achieve a desirable product, we have prepared the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ as an effective and multifunctional heterogeneous photocatalyst for the one-pot tandem aerobic photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation of alcohols with malononitrile. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and devices In this work, all chemicals containing Pluronic P123, TEOS, cyanamide, CoCl2, benzyl alcohols and malononitrile, reagents and solvents are procured from Flucka and Merck companies and utilized without extra purifications. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were obtained by using a Shimadzu 800 IR 100 spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction spectra (PXRD) were performed with a PANAlytical X-PERT-PRO MPD diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å, 40 kV/40 mA). The UV–vis diffuse reflection spectra of the ompg-C3N4 and ompg-C3N4/Co2+ was taken on a UV–vis spectrometer (UV-1700 Shimadzu, Japan). Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were collected on RF-6000 Shimadzo Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) were obtained by VISTA-Pro (Varian-Inc). The morphology and textural properties of the samples were analyzed by MIRA3 TESCAN-XMU. N2 adsorption and desorption measurement were obtained by BET method and BJH model which was conducted on Micromeritics (ASAP 2020) apparatus at −196 °C. STA504 analyzer was used to investigate thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis of as-prepared samples under N2 at 10 °C/min to 800 °C. EDX spectra were acquired on Numerix DXP-X10P. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were done on Bestec GmbH, Berlin, Germany equipped with an Al–Kα X–ray source at energy of 1486.6 eV. A 70 W white LED lamp with a 420 nm wavelength was used a visible light source for photocatalytic activity. Melting-points of the final products were determined using an Electrothermal 9100 apparatus. Proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectra of the products were obtained by Burker DRX-500 Avance spectrometer (500 MHz). 2.2 Preparation of SBA-15 ordered mesostructured silica For the preparation of ompg-C3N4, SBA-15 was utilized as a hard silica template. At first, Pluronic P123 (3.5 g) was dissolved under stirring in HCl (1.6 M) at 38 °C for 24 h, followed by adding 7.5 mL of TEOS (tetraethyl orthosilicate) with strong stirring for another 24 h at 38 °C. The obtained mixture was heated in the Teflon-lined autoclave for 24 h at 150 °C. The resultant white solid was filtered off, then washed by de-ionized water. Finally, the solid was calcined for 5 h at 550 °C in air. 2.3 Preparation of highly ordered mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (ompg-C3N4) The above obtained SBA-15 (1.0 g) was added in 8.0 mL of aqueous solution including 3.5 g of cyanamide and stirred strongly for 8 h. Then, the dispersed mixture was centrifuged and dried overnight at 60 °C. The resulting powder was heated under N2 atmosphere at 550 °C. Subsequently, to remove the SBA-15 as a silica template, the prepared light- yellow solid material was stirred in NH4HF2 (4.0 M, 40 mL) for 24 h. After filtering the precipitate and washing with de-ionized water and ethanol, the light-yellow powder was dried at 60 °C. 2.4 Preparation of ompg-C3N4/Co2+ Briefly, 50.0 mL of aqueous solution including 0.4 g of prepared ompg-C3N4 was sonicated for 30 min to obtain a uniform suspension, then aqueous solution of CoCl2 (250.0 mL, 0.3 M) was added into the above dispersed mixture. The mixture was sonicated for 4 h at 80 °C, followed by centrifugation and washed by de-ionized water for several times to eliminate the unbound CoCl2, finally the powder dried overnight. 2.5 General procedure for one-pot tandem photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation In a 25.0 mL round-bottomed flask, benzyl alcohol (1.0 mmol), ompg-C3N4/Co2+ (80.0 mg), and acetonitrile as solvent (16.0 mL) without any oxidant were mixed and stirred at room temperature under visible light irradiation (70 W LED) in air atmosphere for 12 h. Completion the reaction was determined by TLC, followed by adding of malononitrile (1.1 mmol) and the mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 6 h until Knoevenagel condensation was completed. The catalyst was separated using centrifuge and washed with ethanol and water, dried overnight and used in another cycle. Finally, the solvent was evaporated via rotary and the desired pure product was obtained by recrystallization at ethanol. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations The ordered mesoporous structure of the ompg-C3N4 was investigated by using small angel region of XRD patterns. As reported in the literature, small-angel XRD pattern of 2D hexagonal SBA-15 demonstrates three characteristic peaks matching to the (100), (110), and (200) planes [47,48]. After removal the SBA-15, the intensity of these peaks for ompg-C3N4 decrease and become broader, implying the ordered mesoporous structure of the ompg-C3N4 is less than SBA-15 and 2D hexagonal framework of the template is retained (Fig. 1 ). The wide angle XRD analysis of the prepared ompg-C3N4 displays two distinct diffraction peaks, which corresponding to the interlayer stacking peak of aromatic rings (2θ = 27.4°) and in-plane ordering of tri-s-triazine blocks (2θ = 13.6°). Compared to ompg-C3N4, the strong peak at 2θ = 27.4° become weaker and shifted to the larger angle (by ˜0.4°) with the increase of cobalt ions (Co2+) content in the ompg-C3N4. It is caused by the formation of Co-N bonds through the coordination interaction of Co ions species with ompg-C3N4 and decrease in the distance between the interplanar ompg–C3N4 layers ascribed to the distortion in the in-plane aromatic stacking by the immobilization of Co ions in the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ catalysts. Also another peak at 13.6° is omitted due to the embedding cobalt ions into in-planes of graphitic carbon nitride layers (Fig. 2 ) [49,50]. The FTIR spectra of ompg-C3N4 and ompg-C3N4/Co2+ (Fig. 3 ) confirms the chemical structure of graphitic carbon nitride. The presence of broad bands at 3000–3500 cm−1 displays NH2 and NH groups. The main bands at 1307 and 1602 cm−1 are caused by the stretching vibrations of C–N/CN. Specifically, the sharp signal at 806 cm−1 manifested the presence of the tri-s-triazine rings. The spectrum of ompg-C3N4/Co2+ exhibited the similar characteristic vibrations, clearly reveal that the graphitic carbon nitride framework remains unchanged after the immobilization of Co ions. For determination of the presence of Co species in the ompg-C3N4/Co2+, EDS and ICP-OES analysis has been employed. As depicted in Fig. 4 , three major elements (C, N, and Co) are contributed in the structure of ompg-C3N4/Co2+. These results suggest that the silica template has been successfully removed by washing with NH4HF2. The exact content of Co in the prepared catalyst (ompg-C3N4/Co2+) was obtained 8.04 wt% by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy. The optical features of the synthesized ompg-C3N4 and ompg-C3N4/Co2+ were investigated by UV–vis diffuse reflection spectra (DRS) and room temperature photoluminescence (PL). As can be seen in Fig. 5 , the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ has obvious visible–light absorption. Additionally, the band gap energy (Eg) of the pure ompg-C3N4 and ompg-C3N4/Co2+ were calculated by Taucʼs equation (αhν = B(hν − Eg)n/2) [51] as 2.80 and 2.66 eV respectively. Hence, the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ showed enhanced photocatalytic performance as compared to the ompg-C3N4. To study the charge carrier generation and recombination, the photoluminescence emission spectra (PL) were carried out (Fig. 6 ). The PL spectrum of pristine ompg-C3N4 indicates the maximum PL emission intensity at 480 nm, which related to the high charge recombination. Remarkably, the PL intensity of ompg-C3N4/Co2+ was weaker than ompg-C3N4, implying that the Co species have quenching effect and reduced recombination of the photoinduced electrons and hole pairs. Generally, the narrow band gap and inhibited recombination are vital factors for superior photocatalytic activity. Thermal stability of ompg-C3N4 and ompg-C3N4/Co2+ was examined by thermal gravimetric analysis and differential thermal analysis (Fig. 7 ). The TGA curve of ompg-C3N4 evidence that the catalyst support (ompg-C3N4) is stable up to about 600 °C. The negligible amount of weight loss about 6% at the range of 100–200 °C can be attributed to the evaporation of trapped water molecules by mesopore channels. Also, ompg-C3N4/Co2+ remains stable until 600 °C, which shows a very low loss in the thermal stability with Co immobilization. To further approve the porosity of the prepared ompg-C3N4, the N2 adsorption-desorption analysis were performed. The BET specific surface area, BJH pore size and pore volume of the ompg-C3N4 are shown in Table 1 . The existence of the mosopore structure is confirmed by these results. Moreover, the ompg-C3N4 possess high BET specific surface area (73.8 m2 g−1) and appropriate BJH pore volume (0.128 cm3 g−1) which can provide a promising space for immobilization/ anchoring of Co species. Furthermore, the successful formation of ordered mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride is confirmed by using FESEM. As represented in Fig. 8 , the ompg-C3N4 and ompg-C3N4/Co2+ have rod-like morphology. FESEM images of ompg-C3N4/Co2+ reveal that the surfaces of ompg-C3N4 is decorated with Co species. To further confirm the successful immobilization of Co2+ with ompg-C3N4, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was also carried out. In Fig. 9 (a), the high XPS resolution of Co 2p displays that two pairs of individual peaks at 785.1 and 800.3 eV can be corresponded to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 orbits respectively, which are assigned to Co2+ in ompg-C3N4/Co2+ [49,52]. The binding energy of O 1s at 534.6 eV is ascribed to the surface adsorption and oxidation (Fig. 9b). We also investigated high-resolution of XPS analysis of C 1s and N 1s. The C 1s spectra of ompg-C3N4/Co2+ illustrates two distinct peaks at 287.4 and 290.9 eV, the first peak can be attributed to carbon species for the surface of ompg-C3N4, whereas the second one represents a typical peak for sp2- hybridized carbon which is determined as the NCN bonding of the ompg-C3N4 (Fig. 9c). The high resolution N 1s photoelectron signal of the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ (Fig. 9d) exhibits four peaks located at 401.8, 402.8, 403.3, and 407.1 eV, which are related to the nitrogen atoms in different functional groups: CNC (sp2- hybridized nitrogen), tertiary nitrogen (N−(C)3), uncondensed CNH functional groups, and charging effects or positive charge localization in the heterocycles. These spectral data in comparison with reported pure g-C3N4 [47] indicate binding energy shift to the higher energy due to the incorporation of Cobalt species on the ompg-C3N4/Co2+. 3.2 Catalytic properties One-pot tandem reactions are the most important strategy for organic transformations in the industry and modern synthesis. This strategy has the advantages such as avoiding isolation and purification of the intermediates, reducing energy consumption and production of wastes. Hence, the development of multifunctional heterogeneous catalysts lead to a greener process. The catalytic performance of ompg-C3N4/Co2+ as a multifunctional catalyst was investigated in tandem photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation between 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol and malononitrile as a model reaction for optimization of the reaction conditions (Scheme 1 ). This reaction occurs in one-pot condition including two steps: first, photocatalytic selective oxidation of alcohols, second, Knoevenagel condensation between aldehydes and malononitrile. To optimize the reaction conditions, a series of control experiments was performed (Table 2 ). In the absence of catalyst 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol was not transformed to the corresponding aldehyde, under visible-light or not (Table 2, entries 1, 2). The bulk g-C3N4 gave very low yield of the product under visible light irradiation, and the ompg-C3N4 afforded the desired product with low yield (Table 2, entries 3–10). In the absence of irradiation of visible light, no oxidation proceeded. These results show that the oxidation of alcohol over ompg-C3N4 and ompg-C3N4/Co2+ is a photocatalytic reaction. After immobilization of Co ions, the yield of the product was significantly increased which suggested the essential role of Co species in the photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation and synergistic effect of Co species and ompg-C3N4 in this reaction (Table 2, entries 12–14). The model reaction was carried out in air, O2 and N2 atmosphere and good yield 73% of the desired product was obtained under air and O2 condition (Table 2, entries 12, 14), however the oxidation could not occur under N2 aeration (Table 2, entry 15). In the next step, the model reaction was also examined in the presence of different oxidants such as H2O2 and TBHP, and the results indicated that photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation did not proceed (Table 2, entries 20–22). Various solvents were studied to find the ideal solvent for the aerobic photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel reaction, the desired product was obtained in good yield in acetonitrile. Although low yields were observed in H2O and toluene (Table 2, entries 12, 18, 19). Also, the influence of temperature was studied in the photo-oxidation step of the model reaction. With increasing temperature from 25 to 100 °C, the conversion of corresponding aldehyde was reduced (Table 2, entries 12, 13). To optimize the amount of ompg-C3N4/Co2+ as the catalyst for the one-pot photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation, the model reaction was examined in acetonitrile under visible light irradiation (LED 70W) (Table 2, entries 12, 16, 17). As indicated in Table 2, the best results were achieved in the presence of 100.0 mg of ompg-C3N4/Co2+. The dependence of photocatalytic activity of the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ on the power LEDs was also investigated, and the good yield of the final product was achieved with LED 70 W (Table 2, entries 12, 23–25). Finally, different Co loadings on ompg-C3N4 (8.04%, 5.36%, and 13.4%) were investigated in the model reaction, ompg-C3N4/Co2+ 8.04% exhibited the best catalytic performance in the one-pot photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation reaction (Table 2, entries 12, 26–29). In order to investigate the photocatalytic performance of ompg-C3N4/Co2+, we also used TiO2 P25 as a well-known heterogeneous photocatalyst in the model reaction under the optimal conditions (Table 2, entry 30). No desired product was formed in the presence of TiO2 P25 under visible light irradiation (70W LED). TiO2 P25 displayed a low photocatalytic activity under visible light irradiation. After optimizing the reaction conditions, to explore the applicability of ompg-C3N4/Co2+ for photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation, a series of benzylidenemalononitriles were synthesized by various alcohols including both electron-rich and electron-deficient alcohols (Table 3 ). It should be noted that benzyl alcohols with electron-withdrawing groups gave lower yield of products. Furthermore, aliphatic alcohol (Table 3, entry 10) was also suitable substrate for photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel reaction under the optimal conditions, and produced the desired Knoevenagel condensation product in 40% yield. Based on the photocatalytic performance of ompg-C3N4/Co2+ under visible light, a possible mechanism for the one-pot alcohol photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation was shown in Scheme 2 . The catalytic cycle initiated by exciting electrons from CB of the ompg-C3N4/Co2+, then the photogenerated holes oxidize Co2+ ions into Co3+ species which is a key step in photo-oxidation of alcohols. The electrons react with O2 in the air and generate O2 −. The existence of O2 − and basic properties of the ordered mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (ompg-C3N4) can facilitate deprotonation of benzyl alcohol to produce anion (A), which react with the holes (h+) to produce the carbon radical. Finally, the recombination of the radical (B) with the superoxide radical lead to formation aromatic aldehydes. Due to the presence of the amine groups on the surface of ompg-C3N4, deprotonation of malononitrile occurs. In the next step, the catalyst (ompg-C3N4/Co2+) activates CO bond of aldehyde, then nucleophilic addition of carbanion lead to formation intermediate (I) which undergoes protonation and dehydration to afford benzylidenemalononitrile. Furthermore, trapping experiments were performed to investigate the role of reactive oxidative species. Herein, t-butanol (•OH scavenger), nitrogen (O2 scavenger), and ammonium oxalate (h+ scavenger) were respectively added in the model reaction mixture and irradiated under visible light (70 W LED). As shown in Fig. 10 , t-BuOH showed little effect on the yield of the desired product however, N2 aeration and addition of ammonium oxalate significantly reduced the yield of the product. It was found that O2 and h+ are two essential reactive species in the photocatalytic oxidation reaction. To investigate the stability and recyclability of the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ photocatalyst, a set of experiments were carried out for the one-pot tandem photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation between 4-chlorobenzyl alcohol and malononitrile under similar conditions. When the reaction went to completion, the catalyst was collected by centrifuge, washed with ethanol and water and then dried at room temperature for overnight and reused in the other fresh reaction (Fig. 11 ). It was found that the photocatalytic performance of the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ has no evident decrease even after five consecutive runs. In addition, the Co leaching of ompg-C3N4/Co2+ was evaluated using ICP-OES analysis. The Co concentration was found to be 8.04 wt% before the reaction and 8.03 wt% after the fifth cycle of the reaction. Also the Co leaching was <1 mg L−1 during the hot water treatment, which indicated the strong interaction of Co ions with ompg-C3N4 support. Additionally, FTIR spectra of the used catalyst indicates that the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ had no changes in the chemical structure during the reaction (Fig. 12 ). Compared to the other catalytic system reported in the literature for the one-pot tandem oxidation/ Knoevenagel condensation between benzyl alcohols and malononitrile as an active methylene compound, we herein exhibit that the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ is an efficient photocatalyst for this reaction without any oxidant under air atmosphere and visible light irradiation. As is evident from Table 4 , the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ is comparable with others in terms of reaction conditions, reaction time and non-toxicity solvent. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, Co ions were successfully immobilized on the ompg-C3N4 via a facile sonication treatment. The obtained ompg-C3N4/Co2+ as an effective multifunctional heterogeneous catalyst was utilized for promoting one-pot tandem aerobic photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation of alcohols with malononitrile. The reaction performed without any toxic oxidants under visible light irradiation. No cobalt leaching was occurred during the photocatalytic cycle evaluated by using ICP analysis, revealed the stability and reusability of the ompg-C3N4/Co2+. We believe that the multifunctional nature of the heterogeneous photocatalyst (ompg-C3N4/Co2+) provides a green approach with a reduction in production wastes and energy consumption to access a broad scope of organic compounds from low-cost starting materials through one-pot tandem reactions. coredata.dc:description: Design and synthesis of efficient heterogeneous photocatalysts is an important task for practical applications due to the increasing environmental challenges and energy crisis. In this work, Co2+ modified highly ordered mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (ompg-C3N4/Co2+) was prepared through a simple procedure involving sonication treatment. The obtained catalyst was characterized using FT-IR, XRD, ICP-OES, FE-SEM, UV–vis DRS, N2 adsorption-desorption, and TGA. It was found that the ompg-C3N4/Co2+ can function as a multifunctional heterogeneous photocatalyst for the one-pot tandem selective photo-oxidation/ Knoevenagel condensation. More interestingly, the obtained ompg-C3N4/Co2+ represented a high photocatalytic activity in benzyl alcohol oxidation without any oxidant under air atmosphere and visible light irradiation.
coredata.dc:title: Co2+ immobilized on highly ordered mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (ompg-C3N4/Co2+) as an efficient and recyclable heterogeneous catalyst for one-pot tandem selective photo-oxidation/Knoevenagel condensation
